newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan to halt passengers' flight, delay protests.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan to halt passengers' flight, delay protests.

text.p: Taiwan's civil aviation chief vowed on Monday to end a practice of some Taiwan passengers who, hoping to win financial compensation for flight delays, refuse to leave their seats.
"In the near future, any passengers refusing to leave will be removed forcibly from planes by law enforcers," Civil Aeronautic Administration chief Tsai Duoi told parliament.
Northwest Airlines, United Airlines, Cathay Pacific and Taiwan carrier China Airlines had complained that an apparently growing number of Taiwan passengers were resorting to such action, Tsai said.
Tsai said U.S. officials had lodged a similar complaint to him during recent negotiations in Washington leading to Taiwan's acceptance of the U.S.-inspired "open skies" agreement.
Typically, a passenger angry over a delay simply refuses to disembark at the destination and demands cash compensation.
Such protests stalled six airliners on February 26 alone when fog closed Taiwan's international airport, Tsai said.
Airlines say most delays are unavoidable, involving bad weather, airport congestion or other safety factors.
A Cathay spokeswoman contacted by Reuters acknowledged that the Hong Kong carrier had paid such compensation once, but subsequently had refused similar demands.
Saying the practice was hurting Taiwan's reputation, Tsai said his agency would work out regulations over the next two months to deal with disputes between passengers and airlines.
